Award.AwardTitle: Jacobi matrices, Toda maps, and the absolutely continuous spectrum
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project deals with Jacobi matrices and more general difference operators with some absolutely continuous spectrum and related dynamical properties of such operators. The dynamical systems that are induced by the shift map are relevant when one is interested in the absolutely continuous spectrum, and then maps implemented by Toda flows deserve special attention because they preserve the structural properties of such sytems. The project will pursue this approach and give a prominent role to Toda maps in the study of the absolutely continuous spectrum.

The mathematical questions that will be studied in this project are related to several classical areas of pure mathematics; however, they derive their main motivation from the theory of quantum mechanics. More specifically, they are directly related to questions about the long time behavior of a quantum particle (say, an electron). The rigorous mathematical investigation of such issues often leads to a clearer and more secure understanding of basic mechanisms and subtle effects in the quantum world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, I investigated the spectral properties of Jacobi matrices. This topic is of importance in mathematical physics; Jacobi matrices describe the behavior of a quantum particle in one space dimension. The spectral properties are of interest because they are closely connected to the long time dynamics of the quantum system. In this project, I focused specifically on the absolutely continuous spectrum. This is the part of the spectrum that is associated with scattering behavior: if we are in the absolutely continuous subspace and we fix a region in space, then, given enough patience, we can be almost certain that eventually the particle will not be found in this region.

 

Given this nature of the absolutely continuous spectrum, it now comes as no surprise (and has been well known to mathematicians since the early days of the subject) that absolutely continuous spectrum is determined by what happens far out, at infinity, so to speak. My work puts particular emphasis on limiting operators, which may roughly be described as patterns that are (approximately) observed again and again, if one moves out to infinity. It turns out (and this is a result I obtained somewhat prior to the work on this project) that these limiting operators must be of a very special type when absolutely continuous spectrum is present. The project continues this line of work. The central mathematical objects are these limiting operators and certain dynamical systems, called Toda flows, that evolve Jacobi matrices. While this may seem strange at first (a given physical system corresponds to a fixed Jacobi matrix, so why evolve it?), there are many good reasons for this added flexibility in the setup. I studied the nature of the limit points under these evolutions, and what happens to the absolutely continuous spectrum in such a scenario. One of the main results says that the absolutely continuous spectrum will in fact never get smaller when such a limit is carried out, though it may (or may not) get larger. Another, perhaps more technical, part of the work on the project is concerned with an explicit description of the possible limiting operators in situations where the absolutely continuous spectrum is that of a free particle.
